result.execSummary:
The defendant Rachel A Belanger was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possess/Illegally Obtained Prescription, an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 450.11(7)(h).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt: Statement Regarding Recusal - Molepski, Jr/Judge Finn

Defendant Rachel A Belanger in court with attorney Erik John Mcfarland. Cass Cousins appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
3:37 p.m.  Court calls case.  Atty Cousins states appearances.  Court states this is a Motion to Remove the Pretrial Supervision Program requirement.  Atty McFarland states the Defendant has decided to withdraw the Motion, and enter a plea.  The Defendant has received a new bail jumping charge.  Atty McFarland states they are prepared to enter an agreement.  Atty Cousins states the States recommendation for a plea agreement.

Defendant pleas to Count 3.  Defendant will plea No Contest.  Plea Questionairre has been prepared.  Court questions the Defendant regarding her plea.  Court advises the Defendant regarding her rights.  The Defendant has freely and voluntarily enter her plea.  State agrees to the fact.  Court finds a sufficient basis to support the charge.  Court will find the Defendant guilty to 450.11(7)(h).  Atty Cousins agrees with the joint recommendations at stated.  

BTC:  Court will find the Defendant guilty.  Court will agree with the recommendation, and withhold sentence.  Place the Defendant on Probation for 12 months, with conditions to have an AODA and comply with recommendation.  Participate in any other recommendations of the agent.  Pay costs, not to include the DNA Surcharge.  $100.00 on file to be applied to costs.  Balance to be paid within 60 days.  Court will dismiss and read in Counts 1, 2 and 4.
Motion hearing on August 14, 2014 at 03:30 pm.
Defendant's Notice of Motion and Motion for Modification of Bond filed by Atty Erik McFarland

Atty Erik McFarland appointed

BTC:  Motion denied as this is a Branch 2 case.  Court directs the motion be filed with Branch 2.

Defendant Rachel A Belanger in court with attorney Sean Drury. Cass Cousins appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
  Defendant waives right to Preliminary Hearing.
Court questions the Defendant regarding Waiver of Preliminary Hearing.
Court questions Defendant's attorney.
Court finds the Defendant has freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived the Preliminary Hearing.
On the defendants waiver of the preliminary hearing, Court determines, based on the facts contained in the complaint, there is sufficient probable cause and binds the defendant over for trial. 

  Arraignment:

Defendant received copy of information.
Defendant waives reading of information.

ADA Veronica Isherwood appears in Court.  
Defendant appears from jail by video.

ADA Isherwood states facts for anticipated charges of Possession of Narcotic Drug, Possession of Controlled Substance, Possession of Illegally Obtained Prescription, Possession of Drug Paraphernalia.
Court finds probable cause that a crime has been committed and that this defendant committed it.
Court questions the defendant.
Defendant is employed at Affordable Home and Office Cleaning.  She is paid weekly. 
Atty Isherwood recommends a $200 cash bond with conditions as stated. 
Court questions defendant further.
